metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (Large aperture scintillometer of Daman Superstation, 2020)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the large aperture scintillometer (LAS) at Daman Superstation in the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 6 in 2020. There were two types of LASs at Daman Superstation: BLS900 and RR-RSS460, produced by Germany. The north tower was set up with the BLS900 receiver and the RR-RSS460 transmitter, and the south tower was equipped with the BLS900 transmitter and the RR-RSS460 receiver. The site (north: 100.379° E, 38.861° N; south: 100.369° E, 38.847° N) was located in Daman irrigation district, which is near Zhangye, Gansu Province. The underlying surfaces between the two towers were corn, orchard, and greenhouse. The elevation is 1556 m. The effective height of the LASs was 24.1 m, and the path length was 1854 m. The data were sampled 1 minute at both BLS900 and RR-RSS460.
The raw data acquired at 1 min intervals were processed and quality controlled. The data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods, in which sensible heat flux was iteratively calculated by combining Cn2 with meteorological data according to the Monin-Obukhov similarity theory. The main quality control steps were as follows: (1) The data were rejected when Cn2 exceeded the saturated criterion (BLS900：Cn2>7.25E-14，RR-RSS460：Cn2>7.84 E-14). (2) The data were rejected when the demodulation signal was small (BLS900：Average X Intensity<1000；RR-RSS460：Demod>-20mv). (3) The data were rejected when collected during precipitation. (4) The data were rejected if collected at night when weak turbulence occurred (u* was less than 0.1 m/s). In the iteration process, the universal functions of Thiermann and Grassl (1992) and Andreas (1988) were selected for BLS900 and RR-RSS460, respectively. Detailed can refer to Liu et al. (2011, 2013). Due to instrument adjustment and inadequate power supply, the date of missing data for the large aperture scintillator is: 2020.06.21-2020.06.23；2020.09.21-2020.10.14. 
Several instructions were included with the released data. (1) The data were primarily obtained from BLS900 measurements, and missing flux measurements from the BLS900 instrument were substituted with measurements from the RR-RSS460 instrument. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) The dataset contained the following variables: Date/time (yyyy/m/d h:mm), the structural parameter of the air refractive index (Cn2, m-2/3), and the sensible heat flux (H, W/m^2). In this dataset, a time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30, and the data were stored in *.xlsx format. 
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What does 'eddy covariance system' refer to in the context of measuring turbulent fluxes?
Definition.Answer: An eddy covariance system is a method used to measure and calculate the turbulent fluxes of energy, water vapor, and gases like carbon dioxide and methane between the land surface and the atmosphere. It involves high-frequency measurements of wind speed and scalar quantities, allowing for precise quantification of exchanges in oasis–desert ecosystems, as mentioned in the context of datasets from 2012 to 2021.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using large aperture scintillometers compare to those using eddy covariance systems for measuring energy and water vapor fluxes in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Comparison.Answer: Large aperture scintillometers, like those used in the 黑河流域大满站, focus on measuring sensible heat fluxes by utilizing the refractive index of the air, whereas eddy covariance systems capture turbulent fluxes including both energy and water vapor fluxes. The scintillometer data is collected at a high frequency (1min) but requires integration with meteorological data for processing, while eddy covariance provides half-hourly flux data and can directly measure various parameters including carbon fluxes.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data quality control procedures between datasets collected by automatic weather stations and those collected by large aperture scintillometers in arid and semi-arid regions?
Comparison.Answer: Data collected by large aperture scintillometers undergo quality control steps such as removing saturated data based on specific Cn2 thresholds, weak signal data, precipitation data, and weak turbulence data. In contrast, automatic weather stations provide data with a 10-minute average period and involve standard meteorological observations, which may not require the same specific filtering processes related to Cn2 saturation or weak turbulence.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the effectiveness of quality control measures in data collection methods for large aperture scintillometer observations in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Quality control measures are crucial in ensuring the reliability of data collected by large aperture scintillometers, especially in challenging environments like arid regions. The dataset highlights specific quality control steps, such as removing saturated data, weak signal data, precipitation-affected data, and data with weak turbulence. These steps indicate a rigorous approach to ensure data accuracy and reliability under varying environmental conditions.

Interpretation.Question: How might the data collection techniques employed in oasis–desert ecosystems contribute to understanding the balance between energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of observational datasets from oasis–desert systems, incorporating energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, along with auxiliary data from hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, provides a comprehensive view of ecosystem exchanges. Techniques like eddy covariance systems and scintillometers allow for detailed analysis of these exchanges, contributing to understanding the ecological balance and interactions within the oasis–desert systems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it important to maintain long-term observations in oasis–desert ecosystems when studying energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Long-term observations are crucial to quantitatively understand the basic characteristics and interactions of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, which are vital for achieving sustainable oasis development and ensuring ecological security.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What leads to the data gaps or missing data periods during energy and flux data collection in inland river basins within arid and semiarid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Data gaps or missing periods are often caused by factors like equipment maintenance, insufficient power supply, and signal issues, which can interrupt continuous data collection and lead to incomplete datasets.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the utilization of large aperture scintillometers impact the quality and reliability of data in measuring energy and water vapor exchanges in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of large aperture scintillometers, such as BLS900 and RR-RSS460, allows for the direct measurement of sensible heat fluxes with high temporal resolution. This method contributes to understanding energy exchanges by providing reliable data, especially when supplemented with automatic weather station observations and quality control processes. The effective quality control steps, including excluding saturated data and weak signals, ensure the reliability of the measurements.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of missing data periods on the accuracy and completeness of long-term flux datasets in inland river basins?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Missing data periods, due to issues such as instrument maintenance or power outages, can lead to gaps in long-term datasets, affecting the continuity and completeness of the observations. Such gaps can complicate the analysis of trends and cycles in energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, potentially impacting the understanding of ecological interactions and the development of sustainable management strategies for oasis–desert systems. However, using multiple instruments to fill these gaps, as in the replacement of BLS900 data with RR-RSS460, can mitigate some of these issues.

Causal Consequence.Question: In what ways can integrating datasets from multiple land surface flux and meteorological stations improve the understanding of oasis-desert interactions in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating datasets from multiple stations, including superstations and ordinary stations, enhances the spatial and temporal representativeness of observations. This integration provides comprehensive data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, which is critical for analyzing the interactions between oasis and desert ecosystems. The diverse data collection methods and parameters, such as hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil profiles, support a more detailed and nuanced understanding of these complex systems, contributing to ecological security and sustainable development goals.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop a dataset that captures the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is crucial for achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals. It supports ecological security and sustainable development by providing insights into oasis–desert interactions and their impact on ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind acquiring long-term observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to achieve a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas, which is significant for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and protecting ecological stability. Long-term observations are indispensable for these goals, especially in the context of sustainable oasis development.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are long-term observational datasets collected and maintained for studying energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert systems are collected using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for turbulent flux data, alongside automatic weather stations that provide hydrometeorological data. These datasets include energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, as well as auxiliary data like soil and vegetation parameters. The data collection process ensures comprehensive coverage of environmental parameters and is supported by data archiving and sharing practices to maintain long-term availability.

Enablement.Question: What observational technologies are essential for collecting long-term data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Essential observational technologies include eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for acquiring turbulent flux data, as well as automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data such as radiation, soil heat flux, air temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles.

Enablement.Question: How do data processing and quality control procedures facilitate the reliable collection and use of environmental data in arid and semi-arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: Data processing and quality control procedures involve steps like data collection, processing, and archiving which help in maintaining reliability. Specific quality control steps include removing saturated data, weak signal data, and data during precipitation or under weak turbulence conditions. These ensure the data is accurate and reliable for studying environmental parameters.

Enablement.Question: What infrastructural requirements are necessary to establish and maintain meteorological and flux measurement stations in remote oasis–desert regions?
Enablement.Answer: Infrastructural requirements include well-maintained superstations and ordinary stations equipped with flux measurement technology like large aperture scintillometers and eddy covariance systems. Consistent power supply and maintenance to prevent data loss due to equipment failure are also crucial, as demonstrated by the data gaps due to instrument maintenance and power issues.

Expectation.Question: Why might data collection methods in arid and semi-arid regions face challenges in maintaining long-term observation consistency, particularly in oasis–desert systems?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semi-arid areas face ecological degradation challenges like river and lake drying, vegetation degradation, land desertification, and dust storms, which can affect consistent long-term observations.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise in ensuring the accuracy and reliability of data collected by large aperture scintillometers in complex terrains like the oasis–desert regions?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges in ensuring data accuracy might arise from environmental factors such as instrument maintenance issues, power supply problems, and signal interference, which can lead to data gaps or inaccuracies.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be expectations for datasets involving oasis–desert systems to include a wide range of auxiliary data parameters beyond basic meteorological observations?
Expectation.Answer: Expectations for comprehensive datasets arise because understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange requires auxiliary data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil, which are crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and supporting ecological and socioeconomic stability.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the effectiveness of using large aperture scintillometers for measuring energy fluxes in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of large aperture scintillometers, such as BLS900 and RR-RSS460, appears to be effective for measuring energy fluxes in arid regions like the Heihe River Basin. These instruments allow for detailed analysis of surface processes by providing data on sensible heat flux through iterative calculations based on the Monin-Obukhov similarity theory. The data is thoroughly quality-controlled, and the process includes handling conditions like saturation and weak signal strength. However, challenges such as instrument maintenance and environmental factors causing data gaps highlight the need for robust data collection and quality assurance strategies.

Judgmental.Question: How would you judge the challenges faced in maintaining long-term observational datasets in oasis-desert regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Maintaining long-term observational datasets in oasis-desert regions presents significant challenges, including ecological degradation, drying rivers, vegetation loss, and increased desertification. These environmental crises, exacerbated by climate change, necessitate comprehensive monitoring systems combining field and remote-sensing observations. Additionally, the need for continuous and reliable data for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges further complicates the maintenance of these datasets, as demonstrated by the data gaps seen due to instrument issues and environmental conditions.

Judgmental.Question: What are your thoughts on the potential for expanding datasets related to energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Expanding datasets in arid regions, particularly for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, holds great potential for enhancing our understanding of oasis-desert systems. Given the critical role of these regions in maintaining ecological stability and supporting socio-economic development, there is a need for integrated data collection methods such as eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and comprehensive hydrometeorological observations. The availability of such datasets, as seen with the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center, supports research objectives but requires continuous efforts in data archiving and sharing to ensure access and utility for broader scientific analysis.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced in maintaining continuous data collection in arid and semi-arid regions.
Assertion.Answer: Continuous data collection in arid and semi-arid regions faces challenges such as ecological environment degradation, drying rivers and lakes, natural vegetation degradation, intensified land desertification, and dust storms. Additionally, there are practical issues like instrument maintenance, power supply shortages, and signal problems that can lead to data gaps.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential data collection methods that could enhance the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems beyond the use of scintillometers and eddy covariance systems.
Request/Directive.Answer: In the field of oasis–desert ecosystems, data collection methods could be expanded by integrating remote sensing technologies, which provide large-scale observations and can complement ground-based instruments like scintillometers and eddy covariance systems. Remote sensing can help capture spatial variability and offer insights into land surface conditions over extensive areas. Additionally, deploying drone-based sensors can provide high-resolution data on vegetation and soil parameters, which are crucial for modeling and understanding ecosystem exchanges. Moreover, implementing sensor networks for continuous monitoring of hydrometeorological parameters and utilizing machine learning algorithms for data interpretation can further enhance data collection efforts.
